reasoning: The critique targets an implicit assumption that algorithmic efficiency gains will be broadly visible/usable across the field (via publication/verification), so that “compute-efficient experiments” relax a global compute bottleneck. This is only moderately central: the position’s core claim is about physical/technical substitutability between cognitive labor and compute in AI R&D, and an SIE could occur within a single leading lab even under secrecy. If secrecy dominates, efficiency gains still compound internally, so the critique only weakly undermines the argument rather than refuting it. Correctness is mixed: competitive incentives can push toward secrecy and hype, but the critique overstates this as a Nash-equilibrium certainty and overclaims that the paper’s framework “assumes cooperative knowledge-sharing,” which isn’t clearly required for the main technical points. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: Competitive secrecy prevents algorithmic gains from compounding across labs
